designScenario.name: Landing Gear System
designScenario.description: Design a high-reliability Landing Gear System for an aircraft, integrating advanced deployment/retraction mechanisms, adaptive shock absorption, integrated braking and steering, hydraulic and electric actuation, real-time diagnostics, and thermal management. The system must operate under extreme environmental conditions, ensure safe landings with rapid deceleration, and maintain functionality in emergency scenarios such as hydraulic failure or extreme temperatures. The design emphasizes redundancy, fail-safe protocols, and ease of maintenance to minimize downtime.

details.description: The landing gear must extend and retract reliably on command for takeoff and landing, ensuring alignment with runway conditions.
The system must utilize adaptive shock absorbers that adjust damping based on landing speed and load to minimize impact forces.
The system must deploy the landing gear using a backup pyrotechnic mechanism if primary hydraulic systems fail.
Emergency deployment must occur within 5 seconds of activation, even in zero hydraulic pressure conditions.
The braking system must engage automatically upon gear touchdown to initiate deceleration.
The steering system must provide precise directional control during taxiing with a maximum turning radius of 10 meters.
The system must operate reliably at temperatures ranging from -50°C to +70°C without performance degradation.
All components must withstand exposure to saltwater, sand, and ice without corrosion or mechanical failure.
The system must complete full deployment or retraction in under 2.5 seconds under normal conditions.
Actuation response time must remain consistent at extreme temperatures and altitudes.
The system must support a maximum load of 180,000 lbs during landing and taxiing operations.
Structural components must maintain rigidity under dynamic loads exceeding 200% of the aircraft's maximum weight.
The system must have two independent hydraulic circuits to prevent total failure in case of a single circuit malfunction.
The secondary hydraulic system must activate automatically if the primary system loses pressure.
The landing gear must lock in the extended position if the aircraft's weight exceeds 120% of the gear's capacity during retraction attempts.
A failsafe mechanism must prevent retraction if the gear is not fully locked during deployment.
The system must continuously monitor all critical parameters and provide immediate alerts for anomalies to the flight crew.
Diagnostic data must be transmitted to ground maintenance systems for post-flight analysis.
All major components must be replaceable within 15 minutes using standardized tools.
The system should use modular design principles to allow for quick upgrades and repairs without full system disassembly.
The design must adhere to FAA Part 25 regulations for landing gear systems.
All materials and components must meet ISO 9001 quality management standards.
The system must include cooling mechanisms to prevent overheating of hydraulic fluid and electronic components during prolonged operations.
Thermal sensors must monitor critical components and trigger warnings if temperatures exceed safe thresholds.

relationships.description: The Control Unit aggregates the Thermal Management System to regulate thermal parameters.
The Actuation System relies on the Hydraulic System for primary actuation power.
The Emergency Deployment Mechanism activates based on signals from the Control Unit during failures.
The Landing Gear Doors are part of the Structural Strut Assembly.
The Brake System is mechanically attached to the Wheel Assembly for friction-based deceleration.
The Steering System controls the Nose Wheel Assembly's orientation.
The Sensor Module provides real-time data to the Control Unit for monitoring and control.
The Safety Sensor Array integrates with the Control Unit for fail-safe decision-making.
The Hydraulic Reservoir is a core component of the Hydraulic System.
The Primary Hydraulic Pump supplies pressure to the Hydraulic System under normal conditions.
